description: From Middle English quiver, from Anglo-Norman quivre, from Old Dutch cocare (source of Dutch koker, and cognate to Old English cocer (“quiver, case”)), from Proto-West Germanic *kukur (“container”), said to be from Hunnic, possibly from Proto-Mongolic *kökexür (“leather vessel for liquids”); see there for more. Replaced early modern cocker, the inherited reflex of that West Germanic word.

entries.meaning: (weaponry) A container for arrows, crossbow bolts or darts, such as those fired from a bow, crossbow or blowgun.
examples: Arrows were carried in quiver, called also an arrow case, which served for the magazine, arrows for immediate use were worn in the girdle.

entries.meaning: (figuratively) A ready storage location for figurative tools or weapons.
examples: He's got lots of sales pitches in his quiver.

description: From Middle English quiver, cwiver, from Old English *cwifer, probably related to cwic (“alive”).

adjectives.description: quiver (comparative more quiver, superlative most quiver)

description: From Middle English quiveren, probably from the adjective.

verbs.description: quiver (third-person singular simple present quivers, present participle quivering, simple past and past participle quivered)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To shake or move with slight and tremulous motion.
